channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Roads are jam-packed with traffic while Tubes look even busier
item.description: Photographs taken during rush hour showed queues building up on London roads including the A40 at Perivale and the A102 at Greenwich, while the M5 in Bristol and the M6 in Walsall were also busy.

item.title: NHS issues doctors urgent alert about a coronavirus-related condition in children
item.description: NHS doctors have been issued an urgent alert over a rise in the number of children needing intensive care with a coronavirus-related condition.

item.title: Study finds one in three jobs in parts of Britain are at risk of being lost
item.description: Richmondshire in North Yorkshire, which contains Chancellor Rishi Sunak's Richmond constituency, tops the list of areas most at risk as a result of its large tourism and hospitality sectors.

item.title: Boris Johnson back at work amid calls for coronavirus exit plan
item.description: In a statement in Downing Street, the PM assured the country he is back in charge after weeks recuperating from a serious scare with the killer disease.

item.title: One-year-old girl is killed, and two others hurt in horrific east London 'triple stabbing'
item.description: Police were called at 5.40pm yesterday to reports of a man and two youngsters injured at a home in Ilford. A 12-month-old girl and a three-year-old boy both died.

item.title: Natalie Imbruglia opens up about defying the odds to become a first-time mother in her mid-forties
item.description: The Australian singer, 45, said she felt something was missing from her life before she had son Max via IVF last October.

item.title: Access to PPE for frontline NHS staff is getting WORSE with 27% now unable to get gear
item.description: The Royal College of Physicians said British doctors working in high-risk areas - such as ICU - still could not always access long-sleeved disposable gowns and full-face face visors.

item.title: Firm using magic mushroom ingredient to treat clinical depression raises £64million from investors
item.description: Tech firm Compass Pathways, has raised £64million from investors, including Peter Thiel, the Paypal co-founder. It wants to carry out research into psilocybin from magic mushrooms.

item.title: Sweden shuts five bars and restaurants that refused to observe social distancing rules
item.description: Restaurants and bars are only allowed to provide table service, with tables spaced one to two metres apart to prevent overcrowding, authorities said Sunday.

item.title: Duncan Bannatyne praises NHS staff as he announces the birth of his granddaughter
item.description: The entrepreneur, 71, took to Twitter to praise frontline staff at the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh.

item.title: Saudi Arabia ends death penalty for crimes committed by minors after abolishing flogging
item.description: Minors will now receive a prison sentence of no longer than 10 years in a 'juvenile detention facility'. Pictured: Abdulkareem al-Hawaj was one of the minors executed in 2019.

item.title: Carole Middleton delivers goody bags filled with toys to her local hospital's children's ward
item.description: Carole Middleton, 65, delivered goody bags filled with toys to a local hospital's children ward on Saturday. The photograph is believed to have been shared on her company Party Pieces Instagram.

item.title: Tiny sedge warbler taunts a cuckoo twice his size in this year's best nature photograph
item.description: A stunning shot of a cuckoo being taken on by a tiny warbler in York has won the Society of International Nature and Wildlife Photographers' Living World competition.

item.title: Laurence Fox reveals he considered taking his own life after his divorce from Billie Piper
item.description: The actor, 41, said that the split from the Doctor Who star was so difficult he couldn't see 'the point in being alive'.

item.title: FTSE 100 opens up 1.4% by 83 points to 5,844 as death rates in some of worst-hit countries drops
item.description: The index of Britain's biggest companies is up by 83 points to 5,844 after markets opened today. The positive start followed gains in Asia.

item.title: Dorset Cerne Abbas chalk giant is given face mask by lockdown vandals in lockdown
item.description: Kevin Knight, 43, spotted the unauthorised alteration at 6am on Saturday morning. The Dorset hillside carving was defaced on Friday and the vandalism was criticised by the National Trust.

item.title: Man sues bird breeder for selling him a 'defective parrot' in suit reminiscent of Monty Python skit
item.description: Michael Davy said he bought a male Electus Parrot from fellow Salt Spring Island resident Akhtar Kidwai last year for $2,100, but a month later the bird was diagnoses with a terminal virus.

item.title: New York hospitals are quietly testing heartburn drug famotidine (Pepcid) as treatment for COVID-19
item.description: Northwell Health has been injecting patients in New York with famotidine, sold under brand name Pepcid, after doctors in China noticed people over 80 years old were surviving coronavirus if on the drug.

item.title: Man in his 20s is stabbed to death in east London
item.description: Police were called to Lambert Road (pictured) at 10:26pm last night after the incident. The victim was found with 'apparent stab wounds' and was taken to hospital, where he later died.

item.title: Documentary on Vogue model and photojournalist Lee Miller to air on BBC2
item.description: Lee Miller: A Life On The Frontline will tell the story of the New York fashion model who went from appearing in American Vogue to witnessing first hands the horrors of Nazi Germany.

item.title: Donald Trump wishes 'our great First Lady' Melania a happy 50th birthday
item.description: The Trump family is set to celebrate Melania's golden jubilee birthday in quiet fashion at the White House given nationwide coronavirus lockdowns, according to her chief of staff Stephanie Grisham.

item.title: Britain's most prolific crook is sent back to jail yet again... for his 669th offence
item.description: Britain's most prolific criminal is back in jail after being convicted of his 669th offence. Ryan, from Accrington, Lancashire, was previously jailed in June 2018.

item.title: Doctor with coronavirus falls to her death from hospital in Russia
item.description: Natalya Lebedeva had been accused of failing to stop an outbreak of Covid-19 inside the restricted Star City (file phot) where cosmonauts are trained, colleagues claimed.

item.title: Germany's new coronavirus cases fall to lowest in six weeks with 1,018
item.description: The latest figures bring Germany's total number of infections from 154,175 to 155,193, an increase of just 0.7 per cent which is the lowest since the crisis began.

item.title: The house that inspired Harry Potter
item.description: The notoriously private author and her anaesthetist husband, Dr Neil Murray, are believed to have purchased the home in the Forest of Dean, Gloucestershire, for £399,950 in 2011.

item.title: Should you get stuck into grown-up stickers?
item.description: Dr Susan Mayou of the Cadogan Clinic, claims beauty patches can be effective if they contain logical ingredients. Rachel Carlyle tested out a selection available to buy in the UK.

item.title: New mother reveals she was terrified she would kill her baby due to postpartum psychosis
item.description: Christina Royapen, 28, from Dagenham, east London said she 'shut down emotionally' as she battled to deliver her son, triggering postpartum psychosis - a rare but serious mental illness.

item.title: Cops blast lockdown rules that 'make no sense'
item.description: B&Q's decision to reopen 130 stores saw massive queues forming outside its outlets in Watford (pictured), Edinburgh, Bristol and Swansea, as people used the shutdown to catch up on DIY.

item.title: Moment Porbeagle shark stalks two British fishermen circling off the Channel Islands
item.description: Brandon La Touche and Paris Broe-Bougourd got excited when their fish-finder gave off a large reading just off Guernsey, only to then be greeted by a scene which looked fresh out of a Jaws film.

item.title: Ssh! People reveal why they've kept their relationships a secret from friends and family
item.description: People from around the world have taken to anonymous sharing app Whisper, to confess they're in secret relationships and reveal why they won't tell their friends, family or work colleagues.

item.title: Kim Jong Un 'may have been injured during missile test'
item.description: Former Workers' Party official Lee Jeong Ho told South Korean media that Kim must have been healthy enough to authorise missile tests on April 14 but could have hurt himself in the process.

item.title: Dominic Raab warns Britain will have to adjust to a 'new normal'
item.description: Today guidance drawn up by the British Retail Consortium (BRC) and the shop workers' union Usdaw was released to help shops prepare for the reopening of the UK's high street stores.

item.title: Former tennis prodigy once linked to Nick Kyrgios convicted of drug driving
item.description: Former tennis prodigy Monique Belovukovic, appeared in court for sentencing after she pleaded guilty to driving with an illicit drug present in her bloodstream/oral fluids last month.

item.title: CHRISTOPHER STEVENS reviews the weekend's TV: The most sexist sleuth of the 1970s is back
item.description: CHRISTOPHER STEVENS: The original Dutch detective Piet Van Der Valk made Jack Regan of The Sweeney look like a feminist vegan.

item.title: Cath Kidston staff 'betrayed' over redundancy pay
item.description: Bosses at the company's owner, Barings Asia, are withholding the severance payment. Instead staff have been been told to apply for government handouts.

item.title: Mother-of-two transforms her garage into a colourful playroom decked with rainbows
item.description: Nicole Roberts, 25, of Newport, Shropshire, spent just £450 transforming her garage into a colourful playroom for children Lilly, four, and George, two.

item.title: The mystery of the sapphic suicides
item.description: The deaths of two young women within two days, five miles apart in Essex, presented a case worthy of Sherlock Holmes. For Theodora and Augusta were, it emerged, more than just good friends.

item.title: Queen will send Captain Tom Moore a personalised telegram when he turns 100
item.description: Producers at BBC Breakfast worked alongside Buckingham Palace to organise the celebrations to mark the war hero's big day on Thursday.

item.title: ALISON BOSHOFF asks why fatcats worth millions want taxpayers to cover staff wages during lockdown
item.description: ALISON BOSHOFF: With Prince Charles not asking for help from the Government's coronavirus furlough scheme - but Victoria Beckham among those taking it - it's sparking furious debate.

item.title: Furloughing fat cat bosses pocketed over £300m in five years
item.description: There are mounting calls for super-rich fat cat executives to play a bigger part in shouldering the financial burden stemming from the crisis, which will end up hitting taxpayers hard in the pocket.

item.title: How South Korea can show us the way out of this agony
item.description: In this pandemic, what has struck me most is how prepared South Korea was - in contrast to the faltering West. The battle is now waged on multiple fronts.

item.title: Man, 20, is killed and boy, 16, is fighting for life after separate knife attacks
item.description: Police arrested a 14-year-old boy on suspicion of attempted murder after the attack on Chapelhouse Road in Solihull at around 2.40pm today.

item.title: Doctor creates flashcard system to improve communication
item.description: Anaesthetist Rachael Grimaldi, from Brighton, founded Cardmedic while on maternity leave after reading about a Covid-19 patient who was unable to understand healthcare workers.

item.title: Couple married for 40 years share a final kiss on hospital trolleys
item.description: Tributes have poured in after the death of Carol Kleiman, 78, who was admitted to St James' Hospital in Leeds with her 83-year-old husband Harvey Kleiman on April 1.

item.title: Coronavirus cases in America soar to 987,590
item.description: The total number of coronavirus cases in the US nears one million, as some 12,000 cases are needed to reach the grim milestone

item.title: It's the DOGelgangers! Meet the pet owners who are the perfect match for their pooches
item.description: The Kennel Club is looking for the best doppelgangers for its online show this year. Hannah Martin (pictured), from Essex, makes sure to match her top with dog Lady's (pictured) lead and collar.

item.title: 'Quarantine fatigue' is setting in as data shows people taking more trips since lockdowns began
item.description: Travel plummeted across the US in March when states went into lockdown in an attempt to try and flatten the curve as coronavirus cases and deaths soared.

item.title: I'm a full-time temp but my agency won't furlough me: What can I do?
item.description: I work for a recruitment agency which places me on temporary contracts. They cannot find me a new assignment and they are refusing to furlough me so I now have no income. What can I do?

item.title: Ten tourists who drove more than 200 miles from London to Snowdonia are sent home by police
item.description: A group of ten had driven five hours in two vehicles when they were stopped near their destination on the A5 in Bethesda, North Wales, and sent home again.

item.title: Anti-government protesters return to the streets of Hong Kong
item.description: Chanting popular protest slogans, mostly young activists clad in black swarmed the Cityplaza mall shouting 'Liberate Hong Kong, revolution of our times!'.

item.title: Heated debate sparked over the correct order to organise your kitchen drawers
item.description: A New Zealand father-of-three has sparked debate over the 'right' way to arrange your kitchen drawers after sharing a labelled photo of his layout online.

item.title: Afghan interpreters STILL can't get visas to come to UK
item.description: The Government vowed in March last year that translators who helped British soldiers in the fight against the Taliban could bring their loved ones to join them in the UK.

item.title: The giant Nightingale hospital that hasn't treated ONE patient
item.description: The temporary hospital, which was built in eight days and opened on April 10. But West Midlands mayor Andy Street admitted it has 'not needed to be used'.

item.title: Streatham High Road crash leaves elderly woman in critical condition
item.description: A suspected drug driver is in custody tonight after an elderly woman was hit by a van in Streatham, south London. Police and paramedics were called to Streatham High Road just after 11am on Sunday.

item.title: Wuhan discharges its last coronavirus patient
item.description: Wuhan and the province of Hubei were put in lockdown near the end of January, with roads sealed, trains and planes cancelled and residents unable to move freely for more than two months.

item.title: Cruel PPE profiteers are exploiting coronavirus crisis
item.description: Hundreds of 'PPE pirates and profiteers' are exploiting the coronavirus crisis and putting the lives of key workers at risk as it is below British Standards Institution (BSI) standard.

item.title: Residents dance a socially distant version of Whigfield's famous Saturday Night routine
item.description: Footage taken recently shows a group outside flats in Canon Mooney Gardens in Dublin dancing to Saturday Night by Whigfield.

item.title: Bill Gates defends China over coronavirus response and says criticism of Beijing is a 'distraction'
item.description: 'China did a lot of things right at the beginning, like any country where a virus first shows up,' the Microsoft co-founder told CNN on Sunday. Chinese President Xi Jinping is seen in the inset photo.

item.title: Trump seethes on Twitter about 'fake' news coverage of his work habits
item.description: President Trump claimed on Sunday evening that his use of the word 'noble' instead of 'Nobel' was him being sarcastic to get his point across while discussing New York Times journalists.

item.title: Deserted Nightingale hospitals should be used for elderly patients
item.description: Labour's shadow minister for care and older people Liz Kendall urged ministers to use empty Nightingale hospitals to stop the virus spreading among 500,000 residents and staff in care homes.

item.title: Chef Rob Nixon shares two-ingredient chocolate cake recipe which can be made from eggs and Nutella
item.description: Perth chef Rob Nixon whipped up the indulgent dessert in a TikTok video last Tuesday, calling it 'cheap and easy to make, but delicious' to taste.

item.title: Kim Jong-un 'sent letter of thanks to builders who worked on tourism project'
item.description: North Korean state newspaper Rodong Sinmun has now reported that Kim Jong-un has sent a personal letter to workers on a project in the city of Wonsan.

item.title: Home cook shares her mouthwatering recipe for fluffy cream cheese rolls
item.description: A delighted home baker from Australia has shared photos and the recipe for her cream cheese soft rolls online, wowing thousands with the simple method.

item.title: Victims' families to sue Royal Caribbean cruises over New Zealand White Island volcano tragedy
item.description: Of those who died in the December 9 eruption on New Zealand's White Island, 19 had been on-board the Ovations of the Seas cruise ship and booked to tour the island with Royal Caribbean.

item.title: Blue-ringed octopus crawls out of shell young girl was collecting on Sydney beach
item.description: The man shared a video of the deadly sea creature swimming in a bucket to social media on Friday. He said it was found on Balmoral Beach, in Sydney's North Shore, by a little girl.

item.title: Would-be supermarket queue-jumper tackled to ground and arrested after abusing staff and customers
item.description: Police were called to reports of someone 'behaving aggressively' at the shop in Middleton. Officers arrested a 21-year-old man on suspicion of theft in connection with an earlier incident.

item.title: Enjoy a lighter lockdown with DIY sushi, healthy nuggets for adults, and gourmet sandwiches
item.description: If you've put on weight over the past month, myWW's programme means you'll be spoiled for meal options that can help you to shed the extra pounds you've gained during the lockdown.

item.title: ANDREW PIERCE: Spare us your winks and get a grip, Becky!
item.description: ANDREW PIERCE: Sir Keir Starmer managed to find a place in his Shadow Cabinet for onetime 'Continuity Corbyn' candidate Rebecca Long-Bailey.

item.title: Are you an accepter, a sufferer or a resister? Poll reveals three different 'pandemic personalities'
item.description: Despite the many different facets of quarantine, it seems we all fall broadly into three confinement characters: the accepter, the sufferer and the resister.

item.title: Furloughed British workers could pick fruit and veg suggests Environment Secretary
item.description: The Environment Secretary has used the Government's daily press briefing to suggest furloughed British workers could plug the gap of fruit and veg pickers who have not migrated from Eastern Europe this year.

item.title: New Zealand's south island is struck by 5.6 magnitude earthquake - the biggest to hit this year
item.description: New Zealand has recorded its most powerful earthquake of 2020 in a remote corner of the South Island.

item.title: Indian woman in her 40s 'is gang raped in a school'
item.description: The incident occurred last week in the desert state of Rajasthan when the victim, in her 40s, sought shelter at a police station after walking alone for miles and losing the way to her native village.

item.title: Germans should be given the legal right to work from home
item.description: Hubertus Heil is working on legislation to give employees the right to work from a home office once the Covid-19 virus has passed, so long as their workplace permits it.

item.title: The one lesson I've learned from life: Suggs from Madness says music helps you through bad times
item.description: Graham McPherson, 59, who lives in North London, is best known as Madness frontman Suggs. He says music is an emotional tool that has helped him to get through difficult times.

item.title: The Bill cast REUNITE in uniform from lockdown a DECADE after iconic cop show wrapped
item.description: The cast of The Bill have reunited in uniform at the fictional Sun Hill Police Station, 10 years after the long running ITV drama wrapped.

item.title: A wonderful sunburst of glory: How Princess Margaret, then just 14, described the ecstasy of VE Day
item.description: Today, the concluding part of our gripping minute-by-minute account shows how the nation celebrated with joy - and rather a lot of beer - on that warm spring night 75 years ago.

item.title: Prisoners are drafted in to make much-needed PPE for the fight against coronavirus
item.description: Eight category B and C jails across the UK have been drafted in to help the 'national effort' to sew and make PPE, according to Robert Buckland, the Justice Secretary.

item.title: Harry Dunn 'killer' Anne Sacoolas wants to return to UK to apologise to his parents
item.description: Anne Sacoolas was said to be 'desperate' to return to Britain to meet Charlotte Charles and Tim Dunn but would not surrender to police custody, said a highly-placed source.
item.media:credit: Jamie Wiseman for The Daily Mail

item.title: Simple guide that shows exactly where you're going wrong with your cookies wows thousands
item.description: A simple guide that shows you where you're going wrong with your baking has taken the internet by storm, as men and women continue to turn to baking while stuck in coronavirus isolation.

item.title: U-turn on trans toilets in schools
item.description: Warwickshire County Council said it had withdrawn its 'Trans toolkit', which offered advice to 300 schools, and placed it under review.

item.title: DOMINIC LAWSON: We've been far too cosy with China, but a Tory revolt is fighting back
item.description: DOMINIC LAWSON: How mortifying to be complimented by a representative of the totalitarian regime now in the global dock for its conduct during the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: Phones 4U founder JOHN CAUDWELL: My plan to get us all out of lockdown and back to work
item.description: Phones 4U founder JOHN CAUDWELL: The lockdown has gripped our economy in a deadly embrace - one from which it may never fully recover.

item.title: Just 10 new cases of coronavirus are recorded nationally
item.description: Australia recorded just ten new coronavirus cases on Sunday, Health Minister Greg Hunt said today.

item.title: Making millions didn't make us happy - but our 300 alpacas do!
item.description: Paul Rippon, 48, from Northumberland, who is the founder of online-only bank Monzo, has been married to Debbie, 47, for 27 years. The couple reveal the inspiration behind their alpaca farm.

item.title: 413 coronavirus deaths are recorded in UK today - the lowest figure this month
item.description: The UK's coronavirus death toll increased by 413 today - the lowest recorded this month.

item.title: This is what 62 looks like: Mother-of-five says facials and yoga keeps her youthful
item.description: Kathryn Danzey, 62, who lives in Sheffield with her husband Robert, revealed how monthly facials, at-home yoga and growing her own food contribute to her ageless appearance.

item.title: Why I don't have time to be lonely: BIANCA JAGGER
item.description: Bianca Jagger, 70, who has been in solitary lockdown at her London flat for seven weeks, reveals her routine. Human rights defender is urging the government to make masks mandatory.

item.title: Is it just me? Or do you hate your smug friends, too? asks CLAUDIA CONNELL
item.description: Claudia Connell admits she's becoming increasingly irritated by the behaviour of people that she thought she knew well. British writer is frustrated with braggers who document their day.

item.title: 'Britain's oldest daredevil' dies aged 108 after breaking host of world records after turning 100
item.description: Jack Reynolds, of Derbyshire, was known for his age-defying stunts to raise money for charity. He was the oldest person to ride a rollercoaster and get a first tattoo. He has died at the age of 108.

item.title: Golf clubs hoping to open doors again in mid-May provided players practise social distancing
item.description: With social distancing being something that is fairly easy to achieve when playing the game, the sport was always likely to be in the vanguard when it comes to the easing of the lockdown.

item.title: Shh! Anti-agers no one but you need know about: Can I get a midlife makeover online?
item.description: An anonymous reader asked Inge van Lotringen for advice on improving her make-up skills at home. The British beauty expert suggests a Zoom lesson with Britta D.

item.title: Bank worker who was bullied over disability she got after being hit by a car wins £4.7million payout
item.description: The woman, known only as AB, suffered severe depression and psychosis after six years of humiliation at several branches of NatWest, a tribunal heard.

item.title: How to dress like a grown up with Shane Watson: Ditch the leggings & dig out the denim skirt
item.description: Shane Watson took inspiration from Givenchy's catwalk for embracing this season's denim skirt trend. British style expert suggests opting for skirts that are ankle-grazing and fit like old school jeans.

item.title: Be green and gorgeous: Now you can be eco-chic with a striking collaboration at John Lewis
item.description: Amy Powney who is the creative director of British luxury brand Mother of Pearl, has partnered with John Lewis for a new collection. Anna Pursglove picked out a selection of items from the range.

item.title: Steph & Dom solve your sex, love & life troubles: I think my brother-in-law is flirting with me
item.description: An anonymous reader asked British TV's Steph and Dom Parker for advice. The mother fears her brother-in-law fancies her and says he's been trying to flirt throughout lockdown.

item.title: Jealousy, rows and the agony of isolating with YOUR EX
item.description: UK lawyers are predicting a boom in business post-isolation. Couples who are in the process of separating reveal the challenges of continuing to live together during lockdown.

item.title: RUTH SUNDERLAND: Let's dump Davos elitism
item.description: Even before coronavirus, the World Economic Forum was increasingly irrelevant and seen as a byword for the narcissism of an elite. The creed of globalisation is under challenge.

item.title: Jamie Oliver plans six-figure revamp at his £6million home a year after restaurant chain collapsed
item.description: The celebrity chef, 44, is applying to add new automatic gates, a new drive and to upgrade the oak-panelled library at 16th Century Spains Hall in Finchingfield, Essex.

item.title: Did Trump storm out of coronavirus briefing after he failed to have CNN reporter banished
item.description: The White House tried to move CNN reporter Kaitlan Collins to the back of the room before Trump started his Friday coronavirus press briefing.

item.title: Trevor Phillips' role in Covid-19 BAME inquiry criticised
item.description: Harun Khan, secretary general of the Muslim Council of Britain (MCB), said on Saturday that the decision to appoint Mr Phillips to the inquiry was 'insensitive'.
item.media:description: Trevor Phillips has been appointed to review the impact of coronavirus on black, Asian and minority ethnic (BAME) communities (David Parry/PA)

item.title: First ever proof of meteorite killing a man uncovered in 1888 report to Ottoman sultan
item.description: Documents show Ottoman Sultan Abdul Hamid II (left), was informed of a meteorite that killed one man and paralysed another after landing in Sulaymaniyah, Iraq, on August 22, 1888.

item.title: Teenage cyclist killed in village hit-and-run
item.description: Adam Barry, 15, was struck by a car at 9.15pm on Saturday as he cycled along a road just outside Risley in Derbyshire. He was rushed to Queen's Medical Centre but later died from his injuries.
item.media:description: Adam Barry, 15, died following a hit-and-run collision in Risley, Derbyshire (Handout/Derbyshire Police/PA)

item.title: Personal belongings of an 18 year old soldier killed in the Somme found 90 years later
item.description: Private Tom Ambrose was 'gravely wounded' in the head, leg and arm in 1916. He was rushed to hospital near Calais but died of his injuries. His heartbroken mother hid suitcase inside the loft.

item.title: Germany's far right party AfD's spokesman is suspended after praising 'Aryan' grandfather
item.description: The longtime spokesman of Germany's far right AfD (Alternative for Germany) party has been suspended amid claims he repeatedly described himself as a fascist and praised his 'Aryan' grandfather.

item.title: Politicians are hiding behind 'follow the science' mantra, warns scientist
item.description: Professor Hugh Pennington (pictured), a leading microbiologist at Aberdeen University, who helped discover the first coronavirus in the 1960s says ministers are hoping to avoid blame 'if anything goes wrong'.

item.title: Jeremy Corbyn's brother Piers, 73, leads protest against coronavirus lockdown
item.description: Piers Corbyn spearheaded the rally in Glastonbury, Somerset, against the Government's lockdown, which he said was causing more people to die. He claimed that around 100 attended the protest.

item.title: Britain breaches grim 20,000 death milestone: Another 813 deaths are announced in the UK
item.description: In the daily address to the nation this evening, the Home Secretary said the country was not ready to see an ease in lockdown restrictions which have entered a fifth weekend.
